captions.text: (Guitar music throughout)
Music is a language.

Both music and verbal languages
serve the same purpose.
They are both forms of expression.

They can be used as a way
to communicate with others.
They can be read and written.
They can make you laugh or cry,
think or question,
and can speak to one or many.
And both can definitely make you move.

In some instances, music works
better than the spoken word,

because it doesn't have
to be understood to be effective.

Although many musicians agree
that music is a language,
it is rarely treated as such.
Many of us treat it as something

that can only be learned
by following a strict regimen,
under the tutelage of a skilled teacher.

This approach has been followed
for hundreds of years

with proven success,
but it takes a long time.
Too long.

Think about the first language
you learn as a child.

More importantly,
think about how you learned it.

You were a baby
when you first started speaking,

and even though you spoke
the language incorrectly
you were allowed to make mistakes.
And the more mistakes you made,
the more your parents smiled.

Learning to speak was not something
you were sent somewhere to do
only a few times a week.

And the majority
of the people you spoke to
were not beginners.
They were already proficient speakers.

Imagine your parents forcing you
to only speak to other babies

until you were good enough
to speak to them.

You would probably be an adult before
you could carry on a proper conversation.
To use a musical term,

as a baby, you were allowed
to jam with professionals.

If we approach music
in the same natural way
we approached our first language,

we will learn to speak it
in the same short time
it took to speak our first language.

Proof of this could be
seen in almost any family

where a child grows up
with other musicians in the family.

Here are a few keys to follow
in learning or teaching music.

In the beginning, embrace mistakes,
instead of correcting them.

Like a child playing air guitar,
there are no wrong notes.
Allow young musicians to play
and perform with accomplished musicians
on a daily basis.

Encourage young musicians to play
more than they practice.

The more they play the more
they will practice on their own.

Music comes from the musician,
not the instrument.
And most importantly,
remember that a language works best
when we have something interesting to say.

Many music teachers never find out
what their students have to say.

We only tell them
what they are supposed to say.

A child speaks a language for years
before they even learn the alphabet.

Too many rules at the onset,
will actually slow them down.

In my eyes, the approach to music
should be the same.
After all, music is a language too.

title: Music as a language - Victor Wooten

comments.author: sandra osorio

comments.text:
I'm a singer/guitarist in a band and I've taken no lessons for either. 
 I've been playing guitar for only 4 years and I've been singing for even 
less time.  Not to toot my own horn, because I'm not that flexible, but I 
would say I'm fairly good at both.  I'm a firm believer that if you want to 
play music, the best way is to learn only how to hold an instrument, and 
then take it into a room and start to figure it out.  Then only AFTER 
you've gotten your head around kinda how it works, and how to hold it, 
figure out what you music you want to play, and then just start learning 
it.  The first song I ever learned on guitar was Thunderstruck by ACDC.  I 
had an old acoustic guitar with a REALLY warped neck, and only 1 string, 
with no guitar pick.  So i fashioned one out of a broken CD case that I 
made into a triangle.  The string my guitar had was the second lowest and 
second largest string, the A, and Thunderstruck is played entirely on the 
B, the second highest and second smallest string.  So i tuned the A string 
up to a B note and looked at a tab for which notes to hit.  And slowly but 
surely, I figured out how to play it.  Not very fast or clean, but I could 
do it.  About a month or 2 later I convinced my dad to buy me an electric 
guitar, since the music I wanted to play was rock music.  And with only 
playing for about 2 months on a 'real' guitar, I could already play things 
that my friends that had been taking lessons for over a year, could not.  

The only little artifact that I've acquired that would be considered 
"wrong" is that I also learned Highway to Hell by ACDC shortly after I got 
that guitar, and there is a D over f# chord that you play the low F# with 
your thumb, followed by a G chord in the main riff, that I also played with 
my thumb on the low G.  I saw angus do that in a live video, and to this 
day I still play G chords with my thumb because of that, unless I can't 
because of a change that requires a standard G, but it's still my go to 
fingering for a G chord.  

So in short, I would agree whole heartedly, that learning from a teacher 
makes it much much slower to learn than figuring it out on your own.  ﻿
comments.author: djjazzyjeff123

comments.text:
Interesting topic of discussion. Just came back from practice with a music 
group for the upcoming Easter service with the church choir. Couldn't care 
less if the person sitting adjacent plays violin at a certain grade level. 
Some people in the group may be playing at a higher/more technical level. 
Our job is to get through a few church hymns with a good sound. 

On Christmas went to a dinner gathering. In the room were at least 4 people 
who "supposedly" passed Gr. 6 piano at the conservatory level. Yet not one 
still plays piano. Many people grew up taking music lessons as an academic 
exercise. They would get song books suggested by their teacher. Once they 
are done with each book then what comes next? Even when they get to play a 
Chopin Nocturne they are following an expert teacher in Classical music as 
if there is just 1 correct way of doing the piece.﻿
comments.author: thepianoplayer416

comments.text:
Victor is really on to something here.  I'd love to see him create a music 
curriculum so this can become practical application.  I know when my 
students are given the freedom he speaks of, they leave my class so 
energized and jazzed about music.  Creating music is key, just like 
creating sentences.  ﻿

comments.author: DMD XVII

comments.text:
I agree wholeheartedly with Victor Wooten's take on the best way to learn 
the language of music. But how many children have access to an accomplished 
musician?

In the US schools take music seriously as a subject and recognise it's 
benefits. As a result music is everywhere and American musicians 
continually inspire aspiring musicians throughout the world.

Perhaps in Ireland if Music Education was treated with greater importance 
as a subject, on par with science and maths, then maybe we too could have a 
better music industry as a result. How do you feel about this?﻿
comments.author: mark geary guitar

comments.text: I like how you explained it in your last paragraph. Good points!
comments.author: GERALD ANGELS

comments.text:
Great point Gerald and that is exactly how most people learn today. However 
I think what Victor was getting at was the whole language analogy and 
learning music through conversation on our instruments.
That experience can only happen, as Victor points out, by having access to 
other 'expert' musicians as we learn and then in expressing ourselves in 
our language in a band or jamming situation. Most students I have would say 
they prefer the interaction of a one on one lesson over self study in front 
of a computer.

Again if you take the language analogy, we don't learn to speak our native 
language by listening to audio recordings of our family. We learn by 
interacting, making mistakes and learning how to use this new language to 
communicate in our own individual and creative way. We learn how to express 
ourselves as individuals through this process. If we all could learn music 
in that way perhaps it would be a far more natural process? 

There is room for both I feel but I think we must never lose sight of the 
need to come together and learn how to speak to one another through music.

Do you agree?
comments.author: mark geary guitar

comments.text:
Everyone has access to it, who do you listen to when you hear music? 
"Proffesionals". Simple as that, have access to it anytime of the day. If 
we want to jam with a pro like victor said, all we have to do is put on a 
pair of headphones or blast a pair of speakers... music is everywhere. .. 
we don't physically need someone in front of us to "jam" all we need is 
ourselves and music to listen to.

comments.text:
+Mathieu Hautefeuille De la misma manera que un niño de 6 o 7 años puede 
decir que "odia" la facilidad con la que escribiste este comentario. Victor 
Wooten no tocaba así cuando empezó, eso te lo puedo asegurar sin siquiera 
conocerlo. Es evidente que cada quien tiene sus talentos y sus facilidades 
para aprender una u otra cosa, pero, al final del día, todo se resume en la 
dedicación que le pongas a lo que sea que hagas. A veces, el que tiene más 
talento, no llega lejos, porque se confía y no se esfuerza. Otras veces, el 
que no tiene talento natural, aquel al que le cuesta un montón hacer algo, 
pero tiene la determinación, el deseo y la disciplina necesaria para 
enfocarse en eso, lo logra. Y, algunas pocas veces, como en este caso, se 
suman talento y dedicación y es ahí cuando nacen las súper estrellas, los 
grandes. Yo lo veo así: hay que dedicarle tiempo, ser constante y 
paciente... y los resultados, sean cuales sean, vendrán solos.
comments.author: Fernando González

comments.text:
Odio la facilidad con la que toca... Cuando tú quieres hacer eso, pues 
suena como si echaras el bajo al piso sin querer. 
Pero sí tienen razón, hay que prácticar TODO el tiempo y reírse de nuestros 
errores. En todo, no sólo en la música, en todo en la vida. Hacerlo como 
una urgencia (como niño que quiere aprender) pero con paciencia. Como el 
lenguaje...

comments.text:
+zer0s0und You can find versions of this piece, especially live with an 
audience, without the voice-over, if you search Victor Wooten 'Amazing 
Grace' .. each one is slightly different, including this one .. I'd also 
highly recommend Victor's 'Yesterday' and 'Isn't She Lovely' .. a longer 
version of the talk, without music, you'll find searching for Victor Wooten 
Ted talk .. for me Vic can do no wrong .. a highlight for me of this is the 
room .. WOW !!! .. which I've just found out from the comments section here 
.. thank you Jon Moore !!! .. is David Gage's String Shop, in SoHo NYC .. 
that's where I'm heading right now .. online, LOL (I'm in Australia!) Also, 
Victor writes books, including "The Music Lesson" (thank you Glen 
Scammell!) .. but you'll also find more of Vic's wisdom online too .. and 
you can go see the man himself .. at a concert .. at a workshop .. at a 
camp .. OR .. at a Ted talk .. LOL !!! Life changing stuff !!! Victor, 
you're .. THE MAN !!!

P.S. I see looking back at your comment that you're not a fan of Vic's 
words .. I can't help but say that these words are why Vic creates music 
you want to listen to .. please do check out Vic's Ted talk .. it's goes 
about 18 minutes .. if you do you too may play with as much freedom as Vic 
does .. it's certainly worth thinking about .. it may just change your mind 
.. I think it'll make you smile, at the very least .. and who knows .. one 
day you may even jam with Vic .. he MOST DEFINITELY wouldn't say no, even 
if you've never played before .. please, do go see what he has to say ... 
:-)))

comments.author: Kirsti Cipher

comments.text:
*Music as Language - Victor Wooten*
Victor Wooten is an amazing musician and a passionate educator. 
My son +Felix Stickland posted this a couple of days ago and I  love what 
Victor has to say about music and children.
Personally I am so distracted by his amazing playing on this Ted video that 
it's difficult to appreciate the simple and elegant point that he is 
making, so I found the transcript. His words stand on their own.

I see music, drawing and dance as intrinsic human languages and the way we 
nurture them in our children is crucial to whether we retain, enjoy and 
share their use throughout our lives.


"Both music and verbal languages serve the same purpose.
• They are both forms of expression.
• They can be used as a way to communicate with others.
• They can be read or written.
• They can make you laugh or cry, think or question and can speak to one or 
many.
• And both can definitely make you move.

In some instances music works better than the spoken word, because it 
doesn't have to be understood to be effective. Although many musicians 
agree that music is a language, it is rarely treated as such. Many of us 
treat it as something that can only be learned by following a strict 
regimen, under the tutelage of a skilled teacher. This approach has been 
followed for hundreds of years with proven success, but it takes a long 
time. Too long.

Think about the first language you learn as a child. More importantly, 
think about how you learned it. You were a baby when you first started 
speaking and even though you spoke the language incorrectly you were 
allowed to make mistakes.
And the more mistakes you made the more your parents smiled.

Learning to speak was not something you were sent somewhere to do only a 
few times a week. And the majority of the people you spoke to were not 
beginners. They were already proficient speakers. Imagine your parents 
forcing you to only speak to other babies until you were good enough to 
speak to them. You would probably be an adult before you could carry on a 
proper conversation.

*To use a musical term, as a baby you were allowed to jam with 
professionals.*

If we approach music in the same natural way we aproached our first 
language we will learn to speak it in the same short time it took to speak 
our first language. Proof of this could be seen in almost any family where 
a child grows up with other musicians in the family.

Here are a few keys to follow in learning or teaching music:

• In the beginning embrace mistakes, instead of correcting them. Like a 
child playing air guitar, there are no wrong notes.

• Allow young musicians to play and perform with accomplished musicians on 
a daily basis.

• Encourage young musicians to play more than they practice. The more they 
play the more they will practice on their own.

• Music comes from the musician, not the instrument.

• And most importantly, remember that a language works best when we have 
something interesting to say. Many music teachers never find out what the 
students have to say. We only tell them what they are supposed to say.

• A child speaks a language for years, before they even learn the alphabet. 
Too many rules at the onset, will actually slow them down.

In my eyes, the approach to music should be the same.
After all, music is a language too."
